race.name: Traka 360
race.tagline: Europe's Unbound. 360km through Catalonia from dawn to dusk to dawn. Where WorldTour pros meet gravel specialists.
race.race_challenge_tagline: 360km with 10,000+ feet of climbing on technical Mediterranean terrain

vitals.aid_stations: Multiple feed zones with staffed stops plus town resupply

climate.description: 18-28°C (65-82°F), variable spring weather with morning cold, afternoon heat, possible mountain rain

terrain.primary: Rocky Mediterranean gravel with forest singletrack
terrain.surface: Rocky Mediterranean gravel, forest trails, technical descents—not smooth gravel
features: Forest singletrack that punishes tired legs

gravel_god_rating.tier_note: Europe's largest gravel event, UCI World Series, 4,000+ riders from 74 countries - prestige override applied
gravel_god_rating.tier_override_reason: 1,900+ riders, 'Europe's Unbound' status, Gravel Earth Series flagship, WorldTour pro participation

length.explanation: 360K is 360km (224mi). Also offers 560K ultra (~560km/10,000m), 200K, 100K, 50K. The 360K takes top riders ~12 hours, amateurs 15-30 hours. 560K is multi-day (up to 84 hours). This is European ultra gravel at scale.

technicality.explanation: Much more technical than American gravel. Includes MTB-like singletrack, steep rocky climbs (walking required on some 15%+ sections), loose descents, sandy coastal trails. One 7km singletrack 'strewn with loose rocks' is the 'exhausting highlight.' European gravel skews harder technically.

elevation.explanation: ~3,700m (12,140ft) on 360K. 16 climbs total. First 160km contains two-thirds of the climbing in relentless 'sawtooth' profile. Max elevation only ~500m, but the accumulation is brutal. 560K has 10,000m climbing.

climate.explanation: Generally favorable May weather, but variable. 2024 saw heavy rain and mud; 2023 was perfect. 360K riders face night temps of 8-12°C. Layering required—start cold, heat up, cool down overnight.

altitude.explanation: Low Catalan hills—max ~500m elevation. No altitude concerns. The difficulty is technical terrain and sheer distance, not thin air.

logistics.explanation: Girona is cycling paradise with excellent infrastructure. Fly to Barcelona (BCN) or Girona (GRO). Hotels, restaurants, bike shops everywhere. Start/finish at Parc de les Ribes del Ter. Well-organized with GPS navigation mandatory.

adventure.explanation: From Girona's medieval streets to Pyrenees foothills to Mediterranean coast in one ride. See sunrise, sunset, and sunrise again. Villages, vineyards, sea views, mountain trails. 'The course had everything you can imagine in it.'

prestige.explanation: Dubbed 'Europe's Unbound'—the most prestigious gravel race on the continent. Gravel Earth Series flagship event (1,000 points for 360K winner). Attracts WorldTour pros, ex-pros, and elite gravel specialists. Mattia De Marchi, Ted King, Lachlan Morton all race here.

race_quality.explanation: Exceptional organization. Multi-lingual livestream commentary. GPS navigation mandatory. Feed zones well-stocked. Anti-doping controls for podium finishers. The professionalism matches the prestige.

experience.explanation: The complete gravel experience. Start in darkness with 800 riders' taillights winding up the hill. Race through Catalan countryside, coast, and mountains. Finish in Girona's cycling-obsessed atmosphere. The 'party peloton' grupettos at 2 AM. Unforgettable.

community.explanation: Girona is cycling's spiritual home in Europe. 1,900+ riders from 65+ countries. The shared suffering creates bonds—especially in the overnight hours. The festival atmosphere continues days around the race. 35%+ of field is female.

field_depth.explanation: The strongest gravel field in Europe. WorldTour names (Lachlan Morton, Ted King, Pete Stetina), gravel specialists (De Marchi, Migon), ultra legends (Sehili, Wilcox). 'The level of riders is insane.' Racing at the front is full pro sport.

value.explanation: ~150-200 EUR for 360K is reasonable for an event of this caliber. You get world-class organization and Europe's premier gravel race. Worth the investment.

expenses.explanation: Girona is affordable by European standards—not Paris or London pricing. Barcelona flights are cheap. Many good hotel options. Budget for a multi-day gravel festival trip.

biased_opinion.summary: If you're serious about gravel and have any connection to European cycling culture, Traka is a must. It's not just a race—it's a pilgrimage to the sport's spiritual home. Where else can you suffer on the same roads that Pogačar trains on?
strengths: The location: Girona is cycling heaven. The race is the excuse; the destination is the reward.
The international field: 74 countries. This isn't a regional race.
The legitimacy: UCI points, WorldTour crossover athletes, equal prize purse.
weaknesses: Transatlantic distance: Travel cost and jet lag add complexity for US riders
Crowded early kilometers: 4,000 riders creates bottlenecks
Night racing reality: The 360 almost certainly means riding through darkness
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Traka is Europe's Unbound—and arguably more technical. If European gravel is on your bucket list, this is the defining event.

black_pill.title: THE THING NOBODY TELLS YOU
black_pill.reality: Traka will break you in ways Unbound can't. Some sections are 'questionably rough and better suited to a mountain bike.' Bigger tires are always better—50mm if you can fit them. And Garmin Hill will destroy you after 300km.
consequences: You'll spend $2,000-3,000 minimum (flights, entry, lodging, bike transport)
You'll ride through the night. 12-18 hours means darkness is likely for back-of-pack
The technical descents after 15+ hours test skills you don't have when exhausted
Heat and dehydration in midday Catalan sun—long stretches between resupply if mis-planned
black_pill.expectation_reset: This is a 360km ultra-endurance event with rough terrain. Run the biggest tires you can fit. Plan nutrition carefully. And save something for Garmin Hill.
black_pill.quote: Bigger is always better when it comes to tire choice at The Traka. I was lucky to be able to fit 50mm tires.

final_verdict.one_liner: Europe's Unbound—360km of technical Mediterranean gravel with Garmin Hill waiting to break you at km 300.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes, if you want Europe's premier gravel experience and can handle 12-18+ hours of racing. Traka delivers WorldTour-level legitimacy, stunning Catalan terrain, and a field from 74 countries. Just be ready for rough sections, Garmin Hill after 300km, and run 44-50mm tires.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want European gravel without the ultra distance: Dirty Reiver (UK, 210km). If you want bucket-list adventure: The Rift (Iceland, volcanic terrain). If you want guaranteed good weather: Unbound (Kansas, June).

logistics.lodging_strategy: Book 6+ months early. Race week is chaos. €100-200/night. Consider Barcelona + train to Girona.
logistics.food: Girona has excellent restaurants. Book reservations race week—town fills with cyclists.
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday in Girona. Expo atmosphere, budget 90 minutes.
logistics.parking: Limited. Public transport or hotel shuttles recommended.

history.origin_story: Born in Girona—where WorldTour pros live and train. Exploded from grassroots to Europe's largest gravel event in four years.
notable_moments: Equal prize purse men/women from day one
history.reputation: If Unbound is America's gravel Ironman, Traka is Europe's. The field draws WorldTour crossover athletes and weekend warriors alike.
random_facts: WorldTour pros cross over to race
Girona is cycling's spiritual home—where Pogačar trains

course_description.character: Relentless climbing on Mediterranean gravel. 85% gravel with rough sections better suited to MTB. Flowing early terrain gives way to rougher mid-course chunks.

suffering_zones.label: Early Sectors
suffering_zones.desc: First 135km feels great—flowing terrain outside Girona. But burning matches here costs you later.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Nice flowing terrain, cool morning air

suffering_zones.label: Mid-Race Rough Sectors
suffering_zones.desc: Some sections questionably rough and better suited to a mountain bike. The terrain starts demanding attention.

suffering_zones.label: Garmin Hill
suffering_zones.desc: The steepest, slowest, most brutal climb of the day. Deep into the ride when legs are cooked. This is where races are decided.

suffering_zones.label: Final Flat Run
suffering_zones.desc: After Garmin Hill and one more climb, a long flat roll home. Fatigue and headwind can make riders crawl.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Long flat drag back to Girona

course_description.signature_challenge: Garmin Hill—the steepest, slowest, most brutal climb of the day, hitting when you have 300+ km in your legs.
